items.title: Kevin Muscat's Shanghai Port one of nine Chinese Super League clubs hit with corruption sanctions
items.summary: Kevin Muscat's chances of steering Shanghai Port to a third successive Chinese Super League title have taken a hit with the club to start the season on minus five points after the Chinese FA completed a wide-ranging investigation into corruption.

items.title: 'Good news' for Norway's polar bears, which are growing fatter despite loss of sea ice
items.summary: Polar bears of the Svalbard archipelago have surprised scientists by growing fatter, despite shrinking sea ice, with one theory that the bears are including reindeer and walrus in their diet.

items.title: Genetically modified purple tomatoes bound for fruit shops after regulator approval
items.summary: The purple tomato was altered to make it taste better and boost nutrition.

items.title: WA heatwave causes almost $1 million in crop losses to Gascoyne fruitgrowers
items.summary: Growers in WA's Gascoyne food bowl have lost an estimated $1 million of fruit, with another heatwave on the way.

items.title: Pakistan down Australia by 22 runs in first match of T20 World Cup warm up series
items.summary: Despite the best efforts of evergreen spinner Adam Zampa, Australia have suffered a 22-run defeat to Pakistan in the first T20 of their World Cup preparations.

items.title: Inpex under investigation after suspected sulphur dioxide exposure leaves worker in hospital
items.summary: The Australian Workers' Union has raised concerns after a worker at Inpex's Ichthys gas facility was allegedly exposed to sulphur dioxide and hospitalised, prompting an investigation by the NT workplace safety watchdog.

items.title: SA Arts Minister Andrea Michaels to quit politics after state election
items.summary: Andrea Michaels will not recontest her seat of Enfield, in Adelaide's inner north, but will remain in the cabinet until the March election.

items.title: Thousands of flying foxes die, hundreds rescued, amid record-breaking SA heatwaves
items.summary: A deadly combination of heatwaves has all but decimated a colony of flying foxes in SA's south-east, with surviving bats taken in by conservationists.

items.title: Gold, silver plummet ahead of Fed chair announcement — as it happened
items.summary: The prices of gold and silver have plummeted in Asian trade as markets prepare for a surprise Federal Reserve announcement, and the ASX 200 has finished the week on a negative note. Look back on the day's finance news in our business blog.

items.title: Trump tariffs could 'isolate' the US and create new trading blocs
items.summary: In the past fortnight, US President Donald Trump has threatened tariffs against at least 10 countries. Some experts say the Trump administration's tariff policy is leading to the creation of new trading blocs, and isolating the United States.

items.title: Hastie says he doesn't have support to challenge for Liberal leadership — as it happened
items.summary: Andrew Hastie will not contest the Liberal leadership, clearing the way for a possible challenge to Sussan Ley from Angus Taylor.

items.title: Shoppers remember 'old days' at grocery store that has operated since late 19th century
items.summary: A New South Wales grocery store has been operating since before there was refrigeration, electricity and even Vegemite.

items.summary: As parts of western and south-western New South Wales enter their sixth day of temperatures above 40 degrees, authorities are urging people not to become complacent.

items.title: Adelaide median house price grows $50,000 in a quarter, reaching $925,000 according to Valuer-General data
items.summary: Experts are forecasting continued growth this year as Adelaide's metropolitan median house sale price inches closer to $1 million, according to Valuer-General data.

items.summary: Playing with a chip on his shoulder or feeling slighted is often when 10-time Australian Open champion Novak Djokovic produces his best results.

items.summary: Consumer advocates fear a rate hike when the RBA board meets next week could be the "straw that breaks the camel's back" for borrowers in mortgage stress.

items.title: What could have happened to Celine Cremer, the Belgian tourist who went missing in Tasmania in 2023?
items.summary: Celine Cremer went missing in 2023 from a track in a remote part of Tasmania's north-west. With several recent discoveries in the area, these are the theories of what could have happened.

items.summary: Americans tuned in to watch 45.2 billion minutes of Bluey, Bingo, Bandit and Chilli last year.

items.title: 'Mayhem' as fast-moving bushfire engulfs backyards in suburban Perth

items.summary: The Australian Open will listen to complaints from players like Coco Gauff about behind-the-scenes cameras but remain convinced of their value, Tennis Australia chief executive Craig Tiley says.

items.title: Planning to breastfeed? Preparation can help you meet your goals
items.summary: While most mothers in Australia start breastfeeding, by the time babies are five months old, exclusive breastfeeding drops to 15 per cent. Knowing what to expect — before bub is born — can increase the chances of meeting your breastfeeding goals.

items.title: Most AI assistants are feminine — and it's fuelling dangerous stereotypes and abuse
items.summary: The design choices behind AI technologies — female voices, deferential responses, playful deflections — create a permissive environment for gendered aggression.

items.summary: A US aircraft carrier, supporting warships, fighter jets and air-defence systems have arrived in the Middle East, as the world waits to see to what action — if any — Donald Trump will take against Iran.

items.summary: Construction is underway on the Todd Mall in Alice Springs, with more development planned for the outback town.

items.summary: Data from the country's tertiary admissions centres shows health courses are again the most popular area of study for university students in 2026.

items.summary: Serena Williams offers Coco Gauff some tips on how to smash a racquet properly, while Novak Djokovic gets a dose of luck on court and a little disrespect off it. Here are the quick hits from the Australian Open.

items.summary: The gap between the top seeds and the rest of the players in both the men's and women's draws has resulted in another day filled with straight-sets wipeouts at the Australian Open.

items.title: Rate hike pain is on the way for Australian borrowers, but will they be able to tolerate it?
items.summary: The Reserve Bank cut interest rates three times last year, betting inflation would moderate. But that hasn't happened, and now a rate hike looks likely next month — and possibly another in May.

items.summary: US politicians — both Republican and Democrat — had worried TikTok's Chinese ownership could mean American user data was vulnerable.

items.title: Concerns domestic tenants required to share excessive personal data to secure leases
